Profile 1.Campaign: Phishing campaign using weaponized Microsoft Word documents
Profile 1.Description: APT28 increased its cyber-espionage activities in Central Asia and Kazakhstan, targeting diplomatic, military, and economic entities.

Profile 2.Description: APT4 targets the defense industrial base and other commercial organizations, leveraging spear phishing messages with US government or defense themes.

Profile 3.Description: APT3 targets various industries including aerospace, defense, and telecommunications.

Profile 4.Description: APT12 is believed to be a cyber espionage group linked to the Chinese People’s Liberation Army, targeting journalists, government, and defense industrial base.

Profile 5.Description: APT10 is a Chinese cyber espionage group targeting construction, engineering, aerospace, and telecom firms, as well as governments in the US, Europe, and Japan.

Profile 6.Description: APT9 engages in cyber operations for data theft, focusing on competitive data and projects.

Profile 7.Campaign: Phishing campaign using weaponized Microsoft Word documents
Profile 7.Description: APT28 launched phishing campaigns targeting diplomatic, military, and economic entities in Central Asia and Kazakhstan, using stolen legitimate documents to deliver malware.

Profile 9.Industries: aerospace and defense,construction and engineering,high tech,telecommunications,transportation
Profile 9.Description: APT3 is a Chinese cyber espionage group targeting various industries.

Profile 10.Description: APT4 targets the defense industrial base and other commercial organizations, using spear phishing messages with US government or defense themes.

Profile 11.Description: APT10 is a Chinese cyber espionage group known as Menupass Team.

Profile 12.Description: APT36 is a Pakistan-linked APT group known for targeting Indian government and defense sectors. They use spear-phishing emails with malicious attachments and malware like Crimson RAT.

Profile 13.Description: StrongPity is a Turkey-linked APT group that engages in cyberespionage. They target dissidents, Kurdish groups, and government agencies using watering hole attacks, trojanized installers, keyloggers, and spyware.

Profile 14.Description: The Syrian Electronic Army is a Syria-linked APT group motivated by political influence and hacktivism. They target media and political opponents using website defacements, phishing attacks, and social engineering.

Profile 16.Industries: IT service providers, healthcare, aerospace, government
Profile 16.Description: APT10 is a China-linked APT group involved in cyberespionage and economic gain. They target various industries using supply chain attacks, spear-phishing emails, RATs, credential theft, and lateral movement.

Profile 20.Description: APT12 is believed to be a cyber espionage group thought to have links to the Chinese People's Liberation Army. APT12's targets are consistent with larger People's Republic of China (PRC) goals. Intrusions and campaigns conducted by this group are in-line with PRC goals and self-interest in Taiwan.

Profile 22.Description: APT8 engages in cyber operations where the goal is intellectual property theft, usually focusing on the data and projects that make an organization competitive within its field. We assess that this is a freelancer group located in China with some nation-state sponsorship.

Profile 30.Industries: construction and engineering, aerospace, telecom firms, governments
Profile 30.Description: APT10 is a Chinese cyber espionage group that Mandiant has tracked since 2009. They have historically targeted construction and engineering, aerospace, and telecom firms, and governments in the United States, Europe, and Japan. We believe that the targeting of these industries has been in support of Chinese national security goals, including acquiring valuable military and intelligence information as well as the theft of confidential business data to support Chinese corporations.
